revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-11 19:06:03.000000000', 'message': "Add functional regressions tests for server_group_members OverQuota

Since we started counting quotas in Pike, it is possible to bypass
the server_group_members qouta check if either creating multiple
servers in a single request or creating one server each in multiple
concurrent requests. This is because the server_group_members
count is based on existing server group members in the cell database
and those group members (instances) don't get created in a cell until
we get to conductor and after the scheduler picks a host. In other
words, the server_group_members quota check in the API does not account
for build requests.

Change-Id: Icb268ca2f792bfcefd152ba4c6aa13270d9a7900
Related-Bug: #1780373
(cherry picked from commit f9874e059df50dc81803fcfdfd1045cc09624894)
"}]
commit_message:
Add functional regressions tests for server_group_members OverQuota

Since we started counting quotas in Pike, it is possible to bypass
the server_group_members qouta check if either creating multiple
servers in a single request or creating one server each in multiple
concurrent requests. This is because the server_group_members
count is based on existing server group members in the cell database
and those group members (instances) don't get created in a cell until
we get to conductor and after the scheduler picks a host. In other
words, the server_group_members quota check in the API does not account
for build requests.

Change-Id: Icb268ca2f792bfcefd152ba4c6aa13270d9a7900
Related-Bug: #1780373
(cherry picked from commit f9874e059df50dc81803fcfdfd1045cc09624894)

commit_message:
Cleanup playbook, vars and overrides

1. The venv tag override is unnecessary, given there is a default.
2. The install branch override is unnecessary, given there is a
   default. The constraint in defaults was set to use the
   'cloudkitty_requirements_git_install_branch' instead of this
   variable anyway. This has been corrected to the right var.
3. The galera address for role tests has a specific var for it.
4. The 'cloudkitty_requirements_git_install_branch' is a relic
   of the past, and has been removed.
5. The playbook is very dated and is using a lot of old mechanisms
   and unnecessary vars. It is updated to be normalised with the
   playbooks from the integrated build.

Change-Id: I6a8e8b3ec8b00790416648beb1c4ce0257406409

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-28 12:17:28.000000000', 'message': "Move MQ vhost/user creation into role

There is no record for why we implement the MQ vhost/user creation
outside of the role in the playbook, when we could do it inside the
role.

Implementing it inside the role allows us to reduce the quantity of
group_vars duplicated from the role, and allows us to better document
the required variables in the role. The delegation can still be done
as it is done in the playbook too.

In this patch we implement two new variables:
- cloudkitty_oslomsg_rpc_setup_host
- cloudkitty_oslomsg_notify_setup_host

These are used in the role to allow delegation of the MQ vhost/user
setup for each type to any host, but they default to using the first
member of the applicable oslomsg host group.

We also adjust some of the defaults to automatically inherit existing
vars set in group_vars form the integrated build so that we do not
need to do the wiring in the integrated build's group vars. We still
default them in the role too for independent role usage.

Finally, we remove the test mq setup tasks and clean up any unused
or unnecessary variables configured in tests.

Change-Id: Iac217b80df3da79a944185a90ba4c1ff5409945b

commit_message:
Move MQ vhost/user creation into role

There is no record for why we implement the MQ vhost/user creation
outside of the role in the playbook, when we could do it inside the
role.

Implementing it inside the role allows us to reduce the quantity of
group_vars duplicated from the role, and allows us to better document
the required variables in the role. The delegation can still be done
as it is done in the playbook too.

In this patch we implement two new variables:
- cloudkitty_oslomsg_rpc_setup_host
- cloudkitty_oslomsg_notify_setup_host

These are used in the role to allow delegation of the MQ vhost/user
setup for each type to any host, but they default to using the first
member of the applicable oslomsg host group.

We also adjust some of the defaults to automatically inherit existing
vars set in group_vars form the integrated build so that we do not
need to do the wiring in the integrated build's group vars. We still
default them in the role too for independent role usage.

Finally, we remove the test mq setup tasks and clean up any unused
or unnecessary variables configured in tests.

Change-Id: Iac217b80df3da79a944185a90ba4c1ff5409945b

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-27 14:39:27.000000000', 'message': 'Update to use oslo.messaging service RPC and Notify

This introduces oslo.messaging variables that define the RPC and
Notify transports for the OpenStack services. These parameters replace
the rabbitmq values and are used to generate the messaging
transport_url for the service.

This patch:
* Add oslo.messaging variables for RPC and Notify to defaults
* Update transport_url generation in conf
* Add oslo.messaging to tests inventory and update tests
* Install extra packages for optional drivers
* Add release note

Change-Id: I0612252927f81b3584054f6cd77a2826c5d3fc3b

* Add release note

Change-Id: I0612252927f81b3584054f6cd77a2826c5d3fc3b

commit_message:
Update to use oslo.messaging service RPC and Notify

This introduces oslo.messaging variables that define the RPC and
Notify transports for the OpenStack services. These parameters replace
the rabbitmq values and are used to generate the messaging
transport_url for the service.

This patch:
* Add oslo.messaging variables for RPC and Notify to defaults
* Update transport_url generation in conf
* Add oslo.messaging to tests inventory and update tests
* Install extra packages for optional drivers
* Add release note

Change-Id: I0612252927f81b3584054f6cd77a2826c5d3fc3b

commit_message:
Default MQ RPC/Notify credentials/vhosts to match

When the RPC and Notify service are the same, the credentials
must match - otherwise the tasks to create the user/password
will overwrite with each other.

If the two clusters are different, then the matching credentials
and vhost will not be a problem. However, if the deployer really
wishes to make sure they're different, then the vars can be
overridden.

Also, to ensure that the SSL value is consistently set in the
conf file, we apply the bool filter. We also use the 'notify'
SSL setting as the messaging system for Notifications is more
likely to remain rabbitmq in our default deployment with qrouterd
becoming the default for RPC messaging.

Change-Id: Idf152f2d62466ea53959619c60dd62062d590382

Default MQ RPC/Notify credentials/vhosts to match

When the RPC and Notify service are the same, the credentials
must match - otherwise the tasks to create the user/password
will overwrite with each other.

If the two clusters are different, then the matching credentials
and vhost will not be a problem. However, if the deployer really

Also, to ensure that the SSL value is consistently set in the
conf file, we apply the bool filter. We also use the 'notify'

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary MQ vhost/user creation tasks/vars

There is no record for why we implement the MQ vhost/user creation
outside of the role in the playbook, when we could do it inside the
role.

Implementing it inside the role allows us to reduce the quantity of
group_vars duplicated from the role, and allows us to better document
the required variables in the role. The delegation can still be done
as it is done in the playbook too.

In this patch we remove the test vars and tasks which were duplicated
as they are no longer required.

Change-Id: Ibc217400d16ce06f9943d69e2305e46762ec2662

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-24 07:09:25.000000000', 'message': "Map instances to cell_v2 only once.

If nova-manage cell_v2 create_cell returns 2, it's because the cell already
exists and all instances are correctly mapped to the cell. The cell_v2
map_instances doesn't need to run.

Change-Id: I38002a18dff4dbd44bd3df9e1969c9d50ab12705
Related-Bug: 1729661
(cherry picked from commit 0f24bb8bd45e6c3c4f1dc0fed1418c6be79525ee)
"}]
commit_message:
Map instances to cell_v2 only once.

If nova-manage cell_v2 create_cell returns 2, it's because the cell already
exists and all instances are correctly mapped to the cell. The cell_v2
map_instances doesn't need to run.

Change-Id: I38002a18dff4dbd44bd3df9e1969c9d50ab12705
Related-Bug: 1729661
(cherry picked from commit 0f24bb8bd45e6c3c4f1dc0fed1418c6be79525ee)

commit_message:
Default MQ RPC/Notify credentials/vhosts to match

When the RPC and Notify service are the same, the credentials
must match - otherwise the tasks to create the user/password
will overwrite with each other.

If the two clusters are different, then the matching credentials
and vhost will not be a problem. However, if the deployer really
wishes to make sure they're different, then the vars can be
overridden.

Also, to ensure that the SSL value is consistently set in the
conf file, we apply the bool filter. We also use the 'notify'
SSL setting as the messaging system for Notifications is more
likely to remain rabbitmq in our default deployment with qrouterd
becoming the default for RPC messaging.

Change-Id: I6e3adf764db87d7bced8a2f7eef957cbb2215572

The systemd unit files are being converted to use common roles to reduce
code sprawl throughout the playbooks. This change allows us to use a
common systemd_mount role as an include which will give us a consistent
experience when deploying services and setting up their resournces on
OS's that uses systemd.

commit_message:
Convert role to use a common systemd mount role

The systemd unit files are being converted to use common roles to reduce
code sprawl throughout the playbooks. This change allows us to use a
common systemd_mount role as an include which will give us a consistent
experience when deploying services and setting up their resournces on
OS's that uses systemd.

Closes-Bug: #1774037
Change-Id: I11d083788cd388dab0695878193ab18af1b5038b
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary MQ vhost/user creation tasks/vars

There is no record for why we implement the MQ vhost/user creation
outside of the role in the playbook, when we could do it inside the
role.

Implementing it inside the role allows us to reduce the quantity of
group_vars duplicated from the role, and allows us to better document
the required variables in the role. The delegation can still be done
as it is done in the playbook too.

In this patch we remove the test vars and tasks which were duplicated
as they are no longer required.

Change-Id: I0bd200f584919196e1c4066abed380bf60cd7218

subject: Default MQ RPC/Notify credentials/vhosts to match
messages: [{'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-07-30 11:52:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-07-31 12:20:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2\n\npasses gates, makes things uniform, allow more cleanups later. nice patch.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-07-31 14:01:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-30 11:52:59.000000000', 'message': "Default MQ RPC/Notify credentials/vhosts to match

When the RPC and Notify service are the same, the credentials
must match - otherwise the tasks to create the user/password
will overwrite with each other.

If the two clusters are different, then the matching credentials
and vhost will not be a problem. However, if the deployer really
wishes to make sure they're different, then the vars can be
overridden.

Also, to ensure that the SSL value is consistently set in the
conf file, we apply the bool filter. We also use the 'notify'
SSL setting as the messaging system for Notifications is more
likely to remain rabbitmq in our default deployment with qrouterd
becoming the default for RPC messaging.

Change-Id: Icfebf314963dabd93dd0c5effdbcd0bb4b15571e
"}]
commit_message:
Default MQ RPC/Notify credentials/vhosts to match

When the RPC and Notify service are the same, the credentials
must match - otherwise the tasks to create the user/password
will overwrite with each other.

If the two clusters are different, then the matching credentials
and vhost will not be a problem. However, if the deployer really
wishes to make sure they're different, then the vars can be
overridden.

Also, to ensure that the SSL value is consistently set in the
conf file, we apply the bool filter. We also use the 'notify'
SSL setting as the messaging system for Notifications is more
likely to remain rabbitmq in our default deployment with qrouterd
becoming the default for RPC messaging.

Change-Id: Icfebf314963dabd93dd0c5effdbcd0bb4b15571e

Change-Id: Ib16ff1400d0e5c3e6536a70b4e31e15849958a1c

commit_message:
Add openstack client to Ansible venv

In order for the octavia role to upload the amphora image using
tags, we need to have access to the openstack CLI.

This will be necessary until the Ansible os_image module can
replace this shell task.

Change-Id: Ib16ff1400d0e5c3e6536a70b4e31e15849958a1c

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary MQ vhost/user creation tasks/vars

There is no record for why we implement the MQ vhost/user creation
outside of the role in the playbook, when we could do it inside the
role.

Implementing it inside the role allows us to reduce the quantity of
group_vars duplicated from the role, and allows us to better document
the required variables in the role. The delegation can still be done
as it is done in the playbook too.

In this patch we remove the test vars and tasks which were duplicated
as they are no longer required.

Change-Id: Ife325741032bf6bcda7db6a1fa8b2cba216eeabd

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-06 20:55:08.000000000', 'message': "Create base class for client to avoid code duplication

Implementing listing or showing resource in every client leads to
a lot of duplicated code. To avoid this let's create a base client

commit_message:
Create base class for client to avoid code duplication

Implementing listing or showing resource in every client leads to
a lot of duplicated code. This change adds a base client class
which implements common helpers.

Removes "Database" prefix from class names and "db" infix
from method signatures for alignment with standards from the rest
of the community.

Also, adds doseq option by URL encoding to handle sequence field
values.

Change-Id: I580405e2cb8a15e5735ae413ad2186c620f018bc
Co-Authored-By: Przemyslaw Godek <p.godek@partner.samsung.com>
Co-Authored-By: Krzysztof Opasiak <k.opasiak@samsung.com>
Signed-off-by: Bartosz Zurkowski <b.zurkowski@samsung.com>

commit_message:
Default MQ RPC/Notify credentials/vhosts to match

When the RPC and Notify service are the same, the credentials
must match - otherwise the tasks to create the user/password
will overwrite with each other.

If the two clusters are different, then the matching credentials
and vhost will not be a problem. However, if the deployer really
wishes to make sure they're different, then the vars can be
overridden.

Also, to ensure that the SSL value is consistently set in the
conf file, we apply the bool filter. We also use the 'notify'
SSL setting as the messaging system for Notifications is more
likely to remain rabbitmq in our default deployment with qrouterd
becoming the default for RPC messaging.

Change-Id: If49da70b8b9768d48c09b8fcfca734c9531f1181

commit_message:
[placement] api-ref: add traits parameter

In the "List allocation candidates" API,
the 'traits' parameter is missing.
So add it and update examples.

Change-Id: I4a307759f9e8fa80d003d92142f8e99b2c09c9fe
Partial-Bug: #1778670

commit_message:
Default MQ RPC/Notify credentials/vhosts to match

When the RPC and Notify service are the same, the credentials
must match - otherwise the tasks to create the user/password
will overwrite with each other.

If the two clusters are different, then the matching credentials
and vhost will not be a problem. However, if the deployer really
wishes to make sure they're different, then the vars can be
overridden.

Also, to ensure that the SSL value is consistently set in the
conf file, we apply the bool filter. We also use the 'notify'
SSL setting as the messaging system for Notifications is more
likely to remain rabbitmq in our default deployment with qrouterd
becoming the default for RPC messaging.

Change-Id: I0d5285eeebe94adda39b93e61e79be5673b7347d

commit_message:
Add a simple baremetal functional job

This creates a new job with a limites set of services, including
ironic. Since many regular tests won't work with the baremetal
backend or will take too much, only baremetal tests are run in it.

Change-Id: Ia8af5ebc9aec46d405180f6894dd4228eb816b59

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-18 09:26:54.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] Support for microversions in baremetal resources

The baremetal resources are updated with a _max_microversion reflecting
the currently supported set of fields. Note that it will make create()
call create nodes in the "enroll" state, which is a breaking change.

Change-Id: If46e339070514bcd34bc3ba336f0cfb5556a5cea
'}, {'created': '2018-07-18 09:45:15.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] Support for microversions in baremetal resources

The baremetal resources are updated with a _max_microversion reflecting
the currently supported set of fields. Note that it will make create()
call create nodes in the "enroll" state, which is a breaking change.

Change-Id: If46e339070514bcd34bc3ba336f0cfb5556a5cea
'}, {'created': '2018-07-18 09:49:45.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] Support for microversions in baremetal resources

The baremetal resources are updated with a _max_microversion reflecting
the currently supported set of fields. Note that it will make create()
call create nodes in the "enroll" state, which is a breaking change.

Change-Id: If46e339070514bcd34bc3ba336f0cfb5556a5cea
'}, {'created': '2018-07-19 13:59:13.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] Support for microversions in baremetal resources

The baremetal resources are updated with a _max_microversion reflecting
the currently supported set of fields. Doing that would make create()
call create nodes in the "enroll" state, which would be a breaking change.
Thus, the create() call is updated to handle provision_state being set
to enroll, manageable or available, with available being the default.

Change-Id: If46e339070514bcd34bc3ba336f0cfb5556a5cea
'}, {'created': '2018-07-19 14:21:39.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] Support for microversions in baremetal resources

The baremetal resources are updated with a _max_microversion reflecting
the currently supported set of fields. Doing that would make create()
call create nodes in the "enroll" state, which would be a breaking change.
Thus, the create() call is updated to handle provision_state being set
to enroll, manageable or available, with available being the default.

Change-Id: If46e339070514bcd34bc3ba336f0cfb5556a5cea

commit_message:
Support for microversions in baremetal resources

The baremetal resources are updated with a _max_microversion reflecting
the currently supported set of fields. Doing that would make create()
call create nodes in the "enroll" state, which would be a breaking change.
Thus, the create() call is updated to handle provision_state being set
to enroll, manageable or available, with available being the default.

Change-Id: If46e339070514bcd34bc3ba336f0cfb5556a5cea

group_vars duplicated from the role, and allows us to better document

as it is done in the playbook too.

commit_message:
Move MQ vhost/user creation into role

There is no record for why we implement the MQ vhost/user creation
outside of the role in the playbook, when we could do it inside the
role.

Implementing it inside the role allows us to reduce the quantity of
group_vars duplicated from the role, and allows us to better document
the required variables in the role. The delegation can still be done
as it is done in the playbook too.

In this patch we implement two new variables:
- zun_oslomsg_rpc_setup_host
- zun_oslomsg_notify_setup_host

These are used in the role to allow delegation of the MQ vhost/user
setup for each type to any host, but they default to using the first
member of the applicable oslomsg host group.

We also adjust some of the defaults to automatically inherit existing
vars set in group_vars form the integrated build so that we do not
need to do the wiring in the integrated build's group vars. We still
default them in the role too for independent role usage.

Finally, we remove the test mq setup tasks and clean up any unused
or unnecessary variables configured in tests.

Change-Id: I639a3fa3e138b1ae190325b9794969820267ec23

commit_message:
Set lxc_* vars in one place

Currently there are differing settings for the lxc_* variables
between the test-prepare-host.yml playbook and the test-vars.yml
vars_file. Given that the vars file is used by the same play,
we remove the additional settings given to the roles directly
so that the settings are in one place only.

Change-Id: I1c5813a63c5f4056bb1a2ca306b2bfac2c3d2563

messages: [{'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-07-30 11:59:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-07-31 12:19:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-07-31 14:01:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-30 11:59:00.000000000', 'message': "Default MQ RPC/Notify credentials/vhosts to match

When the RPC and Notify service are the same, the credentials
must match - otherwise the tasks to create the user/password
will overwrite with each other.

If the two clusters are different, then the matching credentials
and vhost will not be a problem. However, if the deployer really
wishes to make sure they're different, then the vars can be
overridden.

Also, to ensure that the SSL value is consistently set in the
conf file, we apply the bool filter. We also use the 'notify'
SSL setting as the messaging system for Notifications is more
likely to remain rabbitmq in our default deployment with qrouterd
becoming the default for RPC messaging.

Change-Id: I488970b695ce439c2de8fa0ad8f04b62882630ff
"}]
commit_message:
Default MQ RPC/Notify credentials/vhosts to match

When the RPC and Notify service are the same, the credentials
must match - otherwise the tasks to create the user/password
will overwrite with each other.

If the two clusters are different, then the matching credentials
and vhost will not be a problem. However, if the deployer really
wishes to make sure they're different, then the vars can be
overridden.

Also, to ensure that the SSL value is consistently set in the
conf file, we apply the bool filter. We also use the 'notify'
SSL setting as the messaging system for Notifications is more
likely to remain rabbitmq in our default deployment with qrouterd
becoming the default for RPC messaging.

Change-Id: I488970b695ce439c2de8fa0ad8f04b62882630ff

commit_message:
Default MQ RPC/Notify credentials/vhosts to match

When the RPC and Notify service are the same, the credentials
must match - otherwise the tasks to create the user/password
will overwrite with each other.

If the two clusters are different, then the matching credentials
and vhost will not be a problem. However, if the deployer really
wishes to make sure they're different, then the vars can be
overridden.

Also, to ensure that the SSL value is consistently set in the
conf file, we apply the bool filter. We also use the 'notify'
SSL setting as the messaging system for Notifications is more
likely to remain rabbitmq in our default deployment with qrouterd
becoming the default for RPC messaging.

Change-Id: I1d56fc82eebfb2d2ed421fd1c589e1b912328c08

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary MQ vhost/user creation tasks/vars

There is no record for why we implement the MQ vhost/user creation
outside of the role in the playbook, when we could do it inside the
role.

Implementing it inside the role allows us to reduce the quantity of
group_vars duplicated from the role, and allows us to better document
the required variables in the role. The delegation can still be done
as it is done in the playbook too.

In this patch we remove the test vars and tasks which were duplicated
as they are no longer required.

Change-Id: I4901fb117ac87ce37e2d07b1691f56820e7b0f70

commit_message:
Default MQ RPC/Notify credentials/vhosts to match

When the RPC and Notify service are the same, the credentials
must match - otherwise the tasks to create the user/password
will overwrite with each other.

If the two clusters are different, then the matching credentials
and vhost will not be a problem. However, if the deployer really
wishes to make sure they're different, then the vars can be
overridden.

Also, to ensure that the SSL value is consistently set in the
conf file, we apply the bool filter. We also use the 'notify'
SSL setting as the messaging system for Notifications is more
likely to remain rabbitmq in our default deployment with qrouterd
becoming the default for RPC messaging.

Change-Id: I618e393b9332eac6fd35472c58dfa2935da09a4d

commit_message:
Move MQ vhost/user creation into role

There is no record for why we implement the MQ vhost/user creation
outside of the role in the playbook, when we could do it inside the
role.

Implementing it inside the role allows us to reduce the quantity of
group_vars duplicated from the role, and allows us to better document
the required variables in the role. The delegation can still be done
as it is done in the playbook too.

In this patch we implement two new variables:
- tacker_oslomsg_rpc_setup_host
- tacker_oslomsg_notify_setup_host

These are used in the role to allow delegation of the MQ vhost/user
setup for each type to any host, but they default to using the first
member of the applicable oslomsg host group.

We also adjust some of the defaults to automatically inherit existing
vars set in group_vars form the integrated build so that we do not
need to do the wiring in the integrated build's group vars. We still
default them in the role too for independent role usage.

Finally, we remove the test mq setup tasks and clean up any unused
or unnecessary variables configured in tests.

Change-Id: I481b2358bf3b93fba3057b825fc9e0f626d616ba

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-30 12:00:44.000000000', 'message': "Default MQ RPC/Notify credentials/vhosts to match

When the RPC and Notify service are the same, the credentials
must match - otherwise the tasks to create the user/password
will overwrite with each other.

If the two clusters are different, then the matching credentials
and vhost will not be a problem. However, if the deployer really
wishes to make sure they're different, then the vars can be
overridden.

Also, to ensure that the SSL value is consistently set in the
conf file, we apply the bool filter. We also use the 'notify'
SSL setting as the messaging system for Notifications is more
likely to remain rabbitmq in our default deployment with qrouterd
becoming the default for RPC messaging.

Change-Id: I0293fef6effefb1e3e7b74e11a10421eb1621b39
"}]
commit_message:
Default MQ RPC/Notify credentials/vhosts to match

When the RPC and Notify service are the same, the credentials
must match - otherwise the tasks to create the user/password
will overwrite with each other.

If the two clusters are different, then the matching credentials
and vhost will not be a problem. However, if the deployer really
wishes to make sure they're different, then the vars can be
overridden.

Also, to ensure that the SSL value is consistently set in the
conf file, we apply the bool filter. We also use the 'notify'
SSL setting as the messaging system for Notifications is more
likely to remain rabbitmq in our default deployment with qrouterd
becoming the default for RPC messaging.

Change-Id: I0293fef6effefb1e3e7b74e11a10421eb1621b39

commit_message:
Default MQ RPC/Notify credentials/vhosts to match

When the RPC and Notify service are the same, the credentials
must match - otherwise the tasks to create the user/password
will overwrite with each other.

If the two clusters are different, then the matching credentials
and vhost will not be a problem. However, if the deployer really
wishes to make sure they're different, then the vars can be
overridden.

Also, to ensure that the SSL value is consistently set in the
conf file, we apply the bool filter. We also use the 'notify'
SSL setting as the messaging system for Notifications is more
likely to remain rabbitmq in our default deployment with qrouterd
becoming the default for RPC messaging.

Change-Id: If95706a85c68767936e7e9d3618e95f5658f5200

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-27 12:19:24.000000000', 'message': 'Remove all MQ vhost/user creation tasks/vars

There is no record for why we implement the MQ vhost/user creation
outside of the role in the playbook, when we could do it inside the
role.

Implementing it inside the role allows us to reduce the quantity of
group_vars duplicated from the role, and allows us to better document
the required variables in the role. The delegation can still be done
as it is done in the playbook too.

In this patch we remove the test-vars which were duplicated from the
role, and remove the MQ setup tasks as they are no longer required.

Change-Id: Ib515630c8fbf793258b40f15a4c9f2c18c4c7531
'}]
commit_message:
Remove all MQ vhost/user creation tasks/vars

There is no record for why we implement the MQ vhost/user creation
outside of the role in the playbook, when we could do it inside the
role.

Implementing it inside the role allows us to reduce the quantity of
group_vars duplicated from the role, and allows us to better document
the required variables in the role. The delegation can still be done
as it is done in the playbook too.

In this patch we remove the test-vars which were duplicated from the
role, and remove the MQ setup tasks as they are no longer required.

Change-Id: Ib515630c8fbf793258b40f15a4c9f2c18c4c7531

commit_message:
Fix quotas retrieval for shares and snapshots tables

After refactoring manila-ui plugin to adapt
to the tabbed quotas interface in horizon,
we stopped accesing the usages data structure
which (in horizon side) carries quotas information.
In this patch set we perform quotas control by
querying manilaclient directly.

Change-Id: I2896d54fde0d5e3975afbb7274faadf2a1a81d7c
Closes-Bug: #1783232
Co-Authored-By: Tom Barron <tpb@dyncloud.net>

commit_message:
Default MQ RPC/Notify credentials/vhosts to match

When the RPC and Notify service are the same, the credentials
must match - otherwise the tasks to create the user/password
will overwrite with each other.

If the two clusters are different, then the matching credentials
and vhost will not be a problem. However, if the deployer really
wishes to make sure they're different, then the vars can be
overridden.

Also, to ensure that the SSL value is consistently set in the
conf file, we apply the bool filter. We also use the 'notify'
SSL setting as the messaging system for Notifications is more
likely to remain rabbitmq in our default deployment with qrouterd
becoming the default for RPC messaging.

Change-Id: I9aa597705514a460a6bc57137b7d2d06bf6b7f05

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-17 21:03:37.000000000', 'message': "Move MQ vhost/user creation into role

There is no record for why we implement the MQ vhost/user creation
outside of the role in the playbook, when we could do it inside the
role.

Implementing it inside the role allows us to reduce the quantity of
group_vars duplicated from the role, and allows us to better document
the required variables in the role. The delegation can still be done
as it is done in the playbook too.

In this patch we implement two new variables:
- congress_oslomsg_rpc_setup_host
- congress_oslomsg_notify_setup_host

These are used in the role to allow delegation of the MQ vhost/user
setup for each type to any host, but they default to using the first
member of the applicable oslomsg host group.

We also adjust some of the defaults to automatically inherit existing
vars set in group_vars form the integrated build so that we do not
need to do the wiring in the integrated build's group vars. We still
default them in the role too for independent role usage.

Change-Id: I97770819e9421ed27575f3fe181b4420742b0820

commit_message:
Move MQ vhost/user creation into role

There is no record for why we implement the MQ vhost/user creation
outside of the role in the playbook, when we could do it inside the
role.

Implementing it inside the role allows us to reduce the quantity of
group_vars duplicated from the role, and allows us to better document
the required variables in the role. The delegation can still be done
as it is done in the playbook too.

In this patch we implement two new variables:
- congress_oslomsg_rpc_setup_host
- congress_oslomsg_notify_setup_host

These are used in the role to allow delegation of the MQ vhost/user
setup for each type to any host, but they default to using the first
member of the applicable oslomsg host group.

We also adjust some of the defaults to automatically inherit existing
vars set in group_vars form the integrated build so that we do not
need to do the wiring in the integrated build's group vars. We still
default them in the role too for independent role usage.

Finally, we remove the test mq setup tasks and clean up any unused
or unnecessary variables configured in tests.

Change-Id: I97770819e9421ed27575f3fe181b4420742b0820

requirements extend beyond those managed by upper-constraints, and

commit_message:
Implement pypi-based install and package pinning for non u-c packages

Rally does not adhere to the global requirements process, so its
requirements extend beyond those managed by upper-constraints, and
sometimes are incompatible with upper constraints.

We have no need to track their development from git commit to git
commit, and can rather rely on stable releases which we verify are
working with the upper constraints whenever we do a pinning bump.

This keeps things simpler for us, and also allows the repo build
process in the integrated build to do a constrained venv build
instead of doing it unconstrained and breaking stable branch builds
down the line.

Closes-Bug: 1782372
Needed-By: https://review.openstack.org/585165
Change-Id: If3d0120cf6f6f78463cf7805bc046382c3b6d44e
(cherry picked from commit 321fb7e69aa4d87b07b1725f37adf0e1b596fcf5)

"}, {'created': '2018-07-27 11:25:04.000000000', 'message': "Move MQ vhost/user creation into role

There is no record for why we implement the MQ vhost/user creation
outside of the role in the playbook, when we could do it inside the
role.

Implementing it inside the role allows us to reduce the quantity of
group_vars duplicated from the role, and allows us to better document
the required variables in the role. The delegation can still be done
as it is done in the playbook too.

In this patch we implement two new variables:
- watcher_oslomsg_rpc_setup_host
- watcher_oslomsg_notify_setup_host

These are used in the role to allow delegation of the MQ vhost/user
setup for each type to any host, but they default to using the first
member of the applicable oslomsg host group.

We also adjust some of the defaults to automatically inherit existing
vars set in group_vars form the integrated build so that we do not
need to do the wiring in the integrated build's group vars. We still
default them in the role too for independent role usage.

Finally, we remove the test mq setup tasks and clean up any unused
or unnecessary variables configured in tests.

Change-Id: I6b781cde4e075dee9d79cf28a55eeda00460c37d
"}]
commit_message:
Move MQ vhost/user creation into role

There is no record for why we implement the MQ vhost/user creation
outside of the role in the playbook, when we could do it inside the
role.

Implementing it inside the role allows us to reduce the quantity of
group_vars duplicated from the role, and allows us to better document
the required variables in the role. The delegation can still be done
as it is done in the playbook too.

In this patch we implement two new variables:
- watcher_oslomsg_rpc_setup_host
- watcher_oslomsg_notify_setup_host

These are used in the role to allow delegation of the MQ vhost/user
setup for each type to any host, but they default to using the first
member of the applicable oslomsg host group.

We also adjust some of the defaults to automatically inherit existing
vars set in group_vars form the integrated build so that we do not
need to do the wiring in the integrated build's group vars. We still
default them in the role too for independent role usage.

Finally, we remove the test mq setup tasks and clean up any unused
or unnecessary variables configured in tests.

Change-Id: I6b781cde4e075dee9d79cf28a55eeda00460c37d

commit_message:
Add ability to suppress OpenStack action exception logging

When OpenStack actions are called, they can sometimes raise exceptions.
Sometimes, those 'exceptions' are actually expected. For instance, if
one wants to probe whether a Swift container exists, one may want the
error, but don't want to log the exception, as it could lead to false
positives in the logs. The 'log_exceptions' parameter to the action
will suppress that log. It defaults to True, as this is the existing
behavior.

Change-Id: I5e453e8d4c08bbcd72d6df61fbea269424c65618
Closes-Bug: #1760883

commit_message:
Improve std.email action

Adds support for cc and bcc addresses to send mails as copy to
administrators and also html formatting. If the html body is specified
the mail will be sent as multipart.

Closes-Bug: #1783349

Change-Id: I2b90354c33052c4b7ae3a98a08e7df1055524a25

[{'created': '2018-07-31 09:23:29.000000000', 'message': 'Delete volume when failed to attach

If failed to attach the volume while calling self.driver.attach_volume,
the function _attach_volume will destroy the Volumemapping table of this
failed volume. So, this failed volume will not be deleted in
_fail_container.
  Delete the volume which auto_remove is true before destroying its
    volumemapping.

    Change-Id: Ie17290703241a2d2ff0a3185cc65eca2bd75f333
    Closes-bug: #1783517

Change-Id: I67c2d3e40a65350f6f8fe6ef2ca5cc63371c194e
'}]
commit_message:
Delete volume when failed to attach

If failed to attach the volume while calling self.driver.attach_volume,
the function _attach_volume will destroy the Volumemapping table of this
failed volume. So, this failed volume will not be deleted in
_fail_container.
  Delete the volume which auto_remove is true before destroying its
    volumemapping.

    Change-Id: Ie17290703241a2d2ff0a3185cc65eca2bd75f333
    Closes-bug: #1783517

Change-Id: I67c2d3e40a65350f6f8fe6ef2ca5cc63371c194e

commit_message:
Using oslo.policy for monasca-log-api

Added policies and used policy enforcement engine
from monasca-common.

- Updated role_middleware to remove authorization into the routes.
- Updated unit tests and implemented some new tests.
- Added a new entry point for generating sample policy file by tox.

story: 2001233
task: 22086

Change-Id: I3d199fac244eca94fc434d19c78bc5a17e804c37
Signed-off-by: Amir Mofakhar <amofakhar@op5.com>

messages: [{'account_id': 2, 'date': '2018-07-31 13:38:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2018-07-31 13:39:56.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-31 13:38:20.000000000', 'message': "Pass microversion info through from Profile

Even though Profile is going away, senlinclient is still using it.
There is a patch up to fix that, but in the meantime, let's fix it for
their issue. api_version in Profile is the variable for setting a
default microversion, but the translation method didn't set it.

Story: 2003146
Change-Id: I6efd25959127bbe28e76b1967caa5b3716346c7e
"}]
commit_message:
Pass microversion info through from Profile

Even though Profile is going away, senlinclient is still using it.
There is a patch up to fix that, but in the meantime, let's fix it for
their issue. api_version in Profile is the variable for setting a
default microversion, but the translation method didn't set it.

Story: 2003146
Change-Id: I6efd25959127bbe28e76b1967caa5b3716346c7e

Initial the unit-tests of OVO for Barbican

This patch set is implement OVOBaseTest
class which will be inherited by subclasses.

It adds TestBarbicanObject and ProjectQuotas class to test
BarbicanObject and ProjectQuotas.

Partial Implements: blueprint rolling-upgrade

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-18 07:56:25.000000000', 'message': "Remove the pcmk_is_remote fact

Since change I61f3393b88b65d29e2f2a5fdf6c2e2a112bfc9a1
(Switch requires for wait-for-settle into resource collectors) we
are not using the pcmk_is_remote fact any longer:
$ grep -r pcmk_is_remote puppet-pacemaker puppet-tripleo
$

It was partially broken anyway: facts run before package installation,
so if pacemaker-remote was not installed it would have returned
false before the configuration.

Let's save ourselves a systemctl call.

Change-Id: Icea3f0535fd8da8d28d269f0984453668424c28d
"}, {'created': '2018-07-30 20:39:51.000000000', 'message': "Remove the pcmk_is_remote fact

Since change I61f3393b88b65d29e2f2a5fdf6c2e2a112bfc9a1
(Switch requires for wait-for-settle into resource collectors) we
are not using the pcmk_is_remote fact any longer:
$ grep -r pcmk_is_remote puppet-pacemaker puppet-tripleo
$

It was partially broken anyway: facts run before package installation,
so if pacemaker-remote was not installed it would have returned
false before the configuration.

Let's save ourselves a systemctl call.

Change-Id: Icea3f0535fd8da8d28d269f0984453668424c28d
"}]
commit_message:
Remove the pcmk_is_remote fact

Since change I61f3393b88b65d29e2f2a5fdf6c2e2a112bfc9a1
(Switch requires for wait-for-settle into resource collectors) we
are not using the pcmk_is_remote fact any longer:
$ grep -r pcmk_is_remote puppet-pacemaker puppet-tripleo
$

It was partially broken anyway: facts run before package installation,
so if pacemaker-remote was not installed it would have returned
false before the configuration.

Let's save ourselves a systemctl call.

Change-Id: Icea3f0535fd8da8d28d269f0984453668424c28d

commit_message:
Specifiy encoding for xml string

In python 3 we need to specify the encoding as "unicode"
otherwise bytes are returned.

Change-Id: I413ea7ec5db3316f985c38900aa46b8cdfd5d138

subject: fix a typo in projects.yaml
messages:
[{'account_id': 17130, 'date': '2018-05-18 16:45:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-05-18 16:56:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 17130, 'date': '2018-05-18 17:08:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-05-18 17:26:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

I'd like to maintain consistency across the file, almost all the other URLs are currently pointing to the Wiki page.. can we maybe decide together if they should all go to docs or Wiki?"}, {'account_id': 17130, 'date': '2018-05-18 19:12:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-05-23 03:48:30.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from fix-url to typo-fix'}, {'account_id': 17130, 'date': '2018-05-23 15:47:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-05-29 09:29:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Rollcall-Vote-1

The "url:" entry is for a pointer to docs about the team itself, it generally points to a wiki page under wiki.o.o. We stopped linking to product documentation in governance with commit fb52d2432793cd7688aa6a8fc115c4ab351b2891.

There are a couple "docs" leftovers though, which I'll clean up in a separate patch.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-05-29 17:22:05.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from fix-url to typo-fix'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-06-01 09:15:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: -Rollcall-Vote

I realize that the wiki page is a bit useless at this stage, but "url:" here should still be pointing to team documentation rather than product documentation...

How about linking to the "contribute" section of the Rally docs ? That could be a good middle ground.

https://rally.readthedocs.io/en/latest/contribute.html'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-06-08 17:13:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Rollcall-Vote-1

I think we either want to change this patch as Thierry suggests, or not change the URL for the team at all.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-06-22 08:47:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Rollcall-Vote-1'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-07-31 13:24:51.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

This change is over 60 days old, so I'm going to clear it from the review dashboard. Please resubmit it when the updated version is ready."}]

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 136, 'name': 'Tim Bell', 'email': 'tim.bell@cern.ch', 'username': 'tim-bell'}, {'_account_id': 782, 'name': 'John Garbutt', 'email': 'john@johngarbutt.com', 'username': 'johngarbutt'}, {'_account_id': 2472, 'name': 'Doug Hellmann', 'email': 'dhellmann@redhat.com', 'username': 'doug-hellmann'}, {'_account_id': 7022, 'name': 'Adam Huffman', 'email': 'adam.huffman@gmail.com', 'username': 'verdurin'}, {'_account_id': 7546, 'name': 'Blair Bethwaite', 'email': 'blair.bethwaite@gmail.com', 'username': 'blairo'}, {'_account_id': 8878, 'name': 'Masahito Muroi', 'email': 'masahito.muroi@linecorp.com', 'username': 'masa'}, {'_account_id': 9003, 'name': 'Tom Barron', 'email': 'tpb@dyncloud.net', 'username': 'tbarron'}, {'_account_id': 10910, 'name': 'Stig Telfer', 'email': 'stig.openstack@telfer.org', 'username': 'stigtelfer'}, {'_account_id': 11564, 'name': 'Chris Dent', 'email': 'cdent@anticdent.org', 'username': 'chdent'}, {'_account_id': 14826, 'name': 'Mark Goddard', 'email': 'mark@stackhpc.com', 'username': 'mgoddard'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 782, 'date': '2018-05-01 08:50:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2018-05-01 08:51:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-05-01 13:37:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote-1

(2 comments)

I like the content, but not the location.

As we discussed on IRC, I've proposed creating a new repository at https://review.openstack.org/565498 

A separate repo will decouple this documentation from "governance" so building various constellations will be less political.

Publishing to docs.openstack.org instead of governance.openstack.org should make the content more discoverable. We can work with the documentation team and other relevant teams to link to the new information from appropriate pages.

Using a new review team should help us avoid having the TC be a bottleneck on creating or reviewing content, long term. We can put the TC in the team to start and then work on recruiting help.

Two comments on the template inline.'}, {'account_id': 7546, 'date': '2018-05-01 14:38:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 10910, 'date': '2018-05-01 16:56:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

Good opener John.  Do you envisage each constellation to be a single file or a multi-file document?  I'm interested in whether/how a little diversity can be included when laying out a reference architecture."}, {'account_id': 136, 'date': '2018-05-01 20:20:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

Add NUMA considerations'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-05-02 09:23:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(5 comments)

Thanks John, looks like a good start.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-05-03 21:43:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The openstack/constellations repository is ready. I have https://review.openstack.org/566171 up now to set up sphinx with no content, so you could apply this change on top of that one to start setting up the directory structure the way you think it ought to be.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-05-04 14:19:06.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 8878, 'date': '2018-05-08 04:44:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-05-10 11:01:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

acknowledging that this is going to move elsewhere but wanted to get some thoughts down and here seems the right place

There's a lot of good information in here but it doesn't currently align with what my perhaps wrong mental model was of what a Constellation is.

What's here is basically presenting the many options and ways of doing scientific computing. The point, as I understood it, of a Constellation was to help narrow choices, not broaden them. This suggests that a scientific computing constellation may be too broad and what we need is a bit more refinement, perhaps couched in an overarching constellation of constellations.

What I would expect to is something like (and in more words): "If you are doing X, Y or Z, then you may find the foobar constellation useful for you, it is made up of the following OpenStack pieces (A, B, C) configured to optimize for blah, bam, boom.

That may not be the right way to go, but the main point is: the document as it currently stands is making it harder to choose, not less.'}, {'account_id': 7022, 'date': '2018-05-10 12:49:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

One typo and one suggestion for more detail.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-07-31 13:24:35.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

This change is over 90 days old and I believe we agreed the new constellations repository was a better place for it, so I'm going to clear it from the review dashboard."}]

commit_message:
Add Scientific Computing constellation

Here is a first draft of what we could include in a constellation,
including a quick introduction to the concept of constellations.

Change-Id: Ia57aa41dd923d1fbc53512f5e10580d5575a4e5f
Task: 8695

subject: Allow projects to drop py27 support in the PTI
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 935, 'name': 'James Page', 'email': 'james.page@canonical.com', 'username': 'james-page'}, {'_account_id': 1736, 'name': 'Ivan Kolodyazhny', 'email': 'e0ne@e0ne.info', 'username': 'e0ne'}, {'_account_id': 2472, 'name': 'Doug Hellmann', 'email': 'dhellmann@redhat.com', 'username': 'doug-hellmann'}, {'_account_id': 4257, 'name': 'Zane Bitter', 'email': 'zbitter@redhat.com', 'username': 'zaneb'}, {'_account_id': 8099, 'name': 'Graham Hayes', 'email': 'gr@ham.ie', 'username': 'graham'}, {'_account_id': 10343, 'name': 'Jim Rollenhagen', 'email': 'jim@jimrollenhagen.com', 'username': 'jimrollenhagen'}, {'_account_id': 10420, 'name': 'Adrian Turjak', 'email': 'devs+openstack@uncaught-exceptions.com', 'username': 'adriant'}, {'_account_id': 11564, 'name': 'Chris Dent', 'email': 'cdent@anticdent.org', 'username': 'chdent'}, {'_account_id': 11904, 'name': 'Sean McGinnis', 'email': 'sean.mcginnis@gmail.com', 'username': 'SeanM'}, {'_account_id': 13252, 'name': 'Dr. Jens Harbott', 'display_name': 'Dr. Jens Harbott (frickler)', 'email': 'frickler@offenerstapel.de', 'username': 'jrosenboom'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2018-04-17 12:12:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2018-04-17 12:35:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Makes sense to me, thanks Graham :)'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2018-04-17 12:55:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2018-04-17 13:20:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-04-17 13:51:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote-1

I don't think we're ready to make python 2 support optional. I do think we should shift to emphasizing python 3 "first", though.

In order to allow projects to drop python 2 support I think we need to wait for both distributions we claim to support to have good python 3 support. Ubuntu has 3.5, but CentOS/RHEL does not, yet. Red Hat has announced in the release notes for RHEL 7.5 that "the next major release" of RHEL will not include python 2 and will include python 3. At that point we can reasonably expect deployers to start deploying OpenStack on python 3, and dropping python 2 support will become a realistic option.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-04-17 13:52:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> I don't think we're ready to make python 2 support optional. I do
 > think we should shift to emphasizing python 3 "first", though.
 > 
 > In order to allow projects to drop python 2 support I think we need
 > to wait for both distributions we claim to support to have good
 > python 3 support. Ubuntu has 3.5, but CentOS/RHEL does not, yet.
 > Red Hat has announced in the release notes for RHEL 7.5 that "the
 > next major release" of RHEL will not include python 2 and will
 > include python 3. At that point we can reasonably expect deployers
 > to start deploying OpenStack on python 3, and dropping python 2
 > support will become a realistic option.

I should add that we have plenty of constructive things to do yet to prepare for that date. The Oslo team is currently working on making python 3 the default for all of our secondary jobs (docs, release notes, pep8, etc.). The next step will be to update the functional test jobs to ensure they are all running under python 3 (at least).'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2018-04-17 14:47:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

So this was discussed in #openstack-tc today.

TL;DR: - We can't make py27 optional and still test on CentOS 7. (which breaks different bits of the PTI)

http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-tc/%23openstack-tc.2018-04-17.log.html#t2018-04-17T13:38:26 -> http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-tc/%23openstack-tc.2018-04-17.log.html#t2018-04-17T14:39:58 

is the relevant bit."}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2018-04-17 14:50:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This could still be merged now (as there is a requirement to be runable in CentOS latest stable) and still require py27 until CentOS 8 is released with py3.x , at which point projects could drop py27.'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2018-04-17 23:22:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I agree that dropping support for existing projects until that point is silly. We should consider how/when to do it, but no one is expecting Nova to go py3 only right now.

But to encourage the py3 first support, and help new projects not have to deal with py27 at all, allowing new projects to be py3 only even if that may stop their immediate adoption is good. It really doesn't make sense to force new projects to support a runtime we know is so close to its end and limit the libraries they then might want to use (provided they don't conflict with global requirements).

Worth noting that a lot of deployers (us too) are in the process of moving to some form of container environments for deployment because then what your underlying OS can do is mostly irrelevant. Plus anyone running the latest release as it comes out is probably running things in containers, or have the ability to iterate quickly, so they are most likely not going to be hugely affected by a switch from py27 to py3."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-04-18 10:55:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

Despite having a useful conversation with Doug about this (thanks very much for that, Doug), I still think we should push forward on this, mostly for the reasons that Adrian says in his comment: new(ish) projects shouldn't have to spend energy on a platform that is at the end of its life.

There's nothing about this change that is forcing projects to drop py27, rather that they are allowed to do so if they feel it is appropriate. I hope we can trust them to make that judgement with an awareness of their users and in consultation with distributors.

Finally, I do not think that the upstream should bear the cost of enabling a downstream to be slow. RHEL's business model is that _they_ do the work to ensure that there is continuity and stability for the enterprise. As a result, they tend to lag the upstream, which is good and fine but it implies a corollary: If the downtream is intentionally lagging, then the upstream needs to be leading. So the downstream can be in the right place at the right time by the time it catches up.

I completely agree that there is plenty to do, besides this change, with regard to python3 preparedness, but this change is one of them."}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-04-18 11:12:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

For what this change is stating, I think we are fine making this change in the PTI.

I'm not sure if we need a larger governance declaration that clears the way for py3-only as well. But I have to agree with Chris that it doesn't feel right for new upstream development to need to be hindered by a slower moving downstream.

Personally, I would like to see new projects only targeting py3, with existing projects trailing on removal of py2 support at a slightly later time."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-04-18 13:16:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The related mailing list thread: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-April/129424.html'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-04-24 08:36:19.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from py3-only-projects to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-04-24 19:14:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> For what this change is stating, I think we are fine making this
 > change in the PTI.

This change will make the PTI self-inconsistent. Dropping the need to run python 2.7 jobs means that we would no longer be enforcing the requirement that projects "run some functional tests" on the platforms we claim to support. https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/project-testing-interface.html#linux-distributions

 > I'm not sure if we need a larger governance declaration that clears
 > the way for py3-only as well. But I have to agree with Chris that
 > it doesn't feel right for new upstream development to need to be
 > hindered by a slower moving downstream.

Nothing about the wording of this change indicates that it applies only to new projects.

 > Personally, I would like to see new projects only targeting py3,
 > with existing projects trailing on removal of py2 support at a
 > slightly later time.

I would prefer that we not establish two classes of projects.'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2018-04-25 08:13:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Doug: Citing from the PTI link you referenced:

"Sometimes, these distributions might not support all dependencies required by new features in OpenStack. Development of these features should not be blocked, though it has to be documented in project release notes, and some tests might have to be skipped on these distributions."

So IIUC projects do have the possibility to avoid py27 already, if it is documented and necessary. Maybe if we amend the wording of this proposal a bit to better match the above paragraph, would that help with your reservations?'}, {'account_id': 935, 'date': '2018-04-25 13:17:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-04-26 13:24:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> @Doug: Citing from the PTI link you referenced:
 > 
 > "Sometimes, these distributions might not support all dependencies
 > required by new features in OpenStack. Development of these
 > features should not be blocked, though it has to be documented in
 > project release notes, and some tests might have to be skipped on
 > these distributions."
 > 
 > So IIUC projects do have the possibility to avoid py27 already, if
 > it is documented and necessary. Maybe if we amend the wording of
 > this proposal a bit to better match the above paragraph, would that
 > help with your reservations?

We make a strong effort to avoid conflicts with old versions or relying on features of new versions of libvirt. I think we should be doing the same for Python.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-April/129866.html for more discussion about a transition plan.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-05-02 19:41:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

There are two things I think we should really try to avoid - because they offer the most pain for the least value:

* New projects that are Python *2* only (I think everyone agrees on this)
* Projects that already support Python 2 & 3 switching to Python 3 only in an uncoordinated fashion

If new projects want to support Python 3 only, in the full knowledge that some distros might not be interested in packaging them for a while yet as a result, then it's their funeral.

I'd like to see us clearly communicate those two expectations (although quite possibly the PTI doc is not the correct place to do that). If we did then I don't see any obstacle to a change to allow new Python 3-only projects. (I believe it's also possible to read all of the review comments so far as not being incompatible with that.)

I'm sympathetic to the idea that packaging for Python 3-only projects on CentOS is RDO's problem and not OpenStack's, but from my investigation it appears that packaging for Software Collections on CentOS 7 is a *different* process from packaging for Python 3 on an OS that has Python 3 by default (like Fedora). So it's a deadweight loss on the distro side with very little apparent benefit (it's not hard to keep a dual-stack application working on Python 2) on the service side."}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2018-05-03 04:44:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> If new projects want to support Python 3 only, in the full
 > knowledge that some distros might not be interested in packaging
 > them for a while yet as a result, then it's their funeral.

In my particular case with Adjutant, I have an upcoming bit of work that will mean choosing between two different libraries for the functionality I need. 

One does support py2/py3 but moving away from it later will be harder, and it doesn't really fulfill all the features I want nor is it a pleasant codebase. The library I want to use is only py3 but it fulfills all my requirements and the codebase isn't as terrifying.

My options:
1. Stick with the worse option because it supports py2 as well.
2. I can make Adjutant use both depending on which is installed, but in doing so limit the features I use to the weaker of the two options or have conditional features depending on which library is in play (maybe doable but more complicated).
3. Go with python3 only and use the better long term option while also gaining the benefit of py3 only features elsewhere.


Option 1 means I'm stuck with a library I don't want to use long term, with a feature set that limits what I can do, and means more work to replace it later. Less work than option 2 though.

Option 2 means a lot more effort to support both, when one option will be deprecated from the get go so I can eventually replace it with one that has more features. This is at least better than option 1 in that at least the py3 only library is already here, and the work is only to remove the py2 option, but does limit the features I can use until dropping py2.

Option 3 is the ideal case. Least amount of work, no need to rework anything, no limits on the features I can use from the libraries I want.

Adjutant isn't an official project yet, it may not end up one, but if it does it likely won't be until the end of Rocky. If made an official project it likely won't be included in any distros until next year, and I'm being clear that the codebase is in flux and we've not hit v1.0.0 yet so distros will likely avoid it for a bit anyway. So in reality I'd be sticking with py2 purely for a potential year or so of inclusion in distros that can't/don't support py3 yet. I'm not sure that's worth it.

I'm pushing for new projects being able to be py3 only because I don't think it's something we should hold against them if they want to become part of the OpenStack ecosystem. Given how much longer python2 has being python3 only is a valid choice right now.

I'm very biased here, but I think for valid reasons. :)"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-05-03 13:41:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> I'm pushing for new projects being able to be py3 only because I
 > don't think it's something we should hold against them if they want
 > to become part of the OpenStack ecosystem. Given how much longer
 > python2 has being python3 only is a valid choice right now.

If we want to have different rules for new and old projects, we need to spell that out clearly inside the text of the governance documents. This patch does not do that."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-05-08 14:00:32.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from formal-vote to on-hold'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-05-08 14:01:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I've set the topic to hold the final decision on this until after the forum session."}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2018-05-08 14:21:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Adrian: I agree with you - especially if you don't forsee packagers taking your project before they switch to py3.x

@Zane: Yeah, it seems Software Collections are really different for packaging / running applications.

That said, should we shoulder the burden (or force a new burden on a team) due to a distro's choice to use docker instead of a standard RPM?"}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-05-11 00:37:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

The move to Python 3 affects many stakeholders. IMHO it's the responsibility of the TC to weigh the interests of all of those stakeholders and organise an orderly transition with predictable timelines, communicated clearly. Good governance demands that we don't just sit back and let every project decide if and when to wag the dog.

That said, I remain fine with allowing it for new projects, because new projects don't tend to have many stakeholders outside of their own teams."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-06-21 19:02:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Graham, do you still want to update this to include the caveats we discussed in Vancouver?'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-07-31 13:24:02.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

This change is over 100 days old, so I'm going to clear it from the review dashboard. Please resubmit it when the updated version is ready."}]

[{'created': '2018-04-17 12:12:11.000000000', 'message': 'Allow projects to drop py27 support in the PTI

With the very short timescales left on python 2.7 [1] we should
allow projects to choose to drop py27 support, and only support
py3.

This makes ``tox -epy27`` optional, like ``tox -epy3`` currently is.

'}]
commit_message:
Allow projects to drop py27 support in the PTI

With the very short timescales left on python 2.7 [1] we should
allow projects to choose to drop py27 support, and only support
py3.

This makes ``tox -epy27`` optional, like ``tox -epy3`` currently is.

1 - https://pythonclock.org/

Change-Id: I6859a76846779ef687422dbbb86483c4a41b55a0
Signed-off-by: Graham Hayes <gr@ham.ie>

[{'created': '2018-07-30 14:32:14.000000000', 'message': 'Do not install linux-image-extra by default

In Ubuntu 14.04, the kernel shipped was lightweight, and some
extra features like using vhost_net, required the package
linux-image-extra.

In Ubuntu 16.04 and above, this is not the case anymore,
as many kernel packages ship with extra features.

vhost_net is generally shipped with the kernel package nowadays
and was the only one documented for the addition of the
linux-image-extra into our roles.

Closes-Bug: 1783342
(cherry picked from commit 8c46d189889987148d6f6906ef2ea66c17f69bed)
'}]
commit_message:
Do not install linux-image-extra by default

In Ubuntu 14.04, the kernel shipped was lightweight, and some
extra features like using vhost_net, required the package
linux-image-extra.

In Ubuntu 16.04 and above, this is not the case anymore,
as many kernel packages ship with extra features.

vhost_net is generally shipped with the kernel package nowadays
and was the only one documented for the addition of the
linux-image-extra into our roles.

Change-Id: I579484ccefe0f29c40f8fed4b2d1b73aaeb917b1
Closes-Bug: 1783342
(cherry picked from commit 8c46d189889987148d6f6906ef2ea66c17f69bed)

commit_message:
Do not install linux-image-extra by default

In Ubuntu 14.04, the kernel shipped was lightweight, and some
extra features like using vhost_net, required the package
linux-image-extra.

In Ubuntu 16.04 and above, this is not the case anymore,
as many kernel packages ship with extra features.

vhost_net is generally shipped with the kernel package nowadays
and was the only one documented for the addition of the
linux-image-extra into our roles.

Change-Id: I579484ccefe0f29c40f8fed4b2d1b73aaeb917b1
Closes-Bug: 1783342
(cherry picked from commit 8c46d189889987148d6f6906ef2ea66c17f69bed)

Update reno for stable/rocky

[{'created': '2018-07-17 21:02:13.000000000', 'message': "Move MQ vhost/user creation into role

There is no record for why we implement the MQ vhost/user creation
outside of the role in the playbook, when we could do it inside the
role.

Implementing it inside the role allows us to reduce the quantity of
group_vars duplicated from the role, and allows us to better document
the required variables in the role. The delegation can still be done
as it is done in the playbook too.

In this patch we implement two new variables:
- barbican_oslomsg_rpc_setup_host
- barbican_oslomsg_notify_setup_host

These are used in the role to allow delegation of the MQ vhost/user
setup for each type to any host, but they default to using the first
member of the applicable oslomsg host group.

We also adjust some of the defaults to automatically inherit existing
vars set in group_vars form the integrated build so that we do not
need to do the wiring in the integrated build's group vars. We still
default them in the role too for independent role usage.

Change-Id: I8e873ad9dc8184ec387fe5e1bd95af1b90bb7233

commit_message:
Move MQ vhost/user creation into role

There is no record for why we implement the MQ vhost/user creation
outside of the role in the playbook, when we could do it inside the
role.

Implementing it inside the role allows us to reduce the quantity of
group_vars duplicated from the role, and allows us to better document
the required variables in the role. The delegation can still be done
as it is done in the playbook too.

In this patch we implement two new variables:
- barbican_oslomsg_rpc_setup_host
- barbican_oslomsg_notify_setup_host

These are used in the role to allow delegation of the MQ vhost/user
setup for each type to any host, but they default to using the first
member of the applicable oslomsg host group.

We also adjust some of the defaults to automatically inherit existing
vars set in group_vars form the integrated build so that we do not
need to do the wiring in the integrated build's group vars. We still
default them in the role too for independent role usage.

Finally, we remove the test mq setup tasks and clean up any unused
or unnecessary variables configured in tests.

Change-Id: I8e873ad9dc8184ec387fe5e1bd95af1b90bb7233

commit_message:
Do not target Redis over TLS when using HA Redis profile

In Pike, Redis doesn't support being accessed over a TLS tunnel when
configured for HA deployments.

Fix the Redis service configuration by force-disabling the TLS
bits in the generated Redis config, as well as in the Redis clients
configuration (gnocchi_api and HAProxy). The hiera keys are
defined in service_config_settings to be compatible with composable HA.

Change-Id: I1602f2b90d7166df05e9a34057064010d6a31afe
Closes-Bug: 1784205
Depends-On: I3b50ebf50046d33d49fbb555c2ee3bc6b3c2eaf9

commit_message:
Do not target Redis over TLS when using HA Redis profile

In Pike Redis doesn't support being accessed over a TLS tunnel when
configured for HA deployments.

Make sure the Redis clients (gnocchi and HAProxy) won't use TLS to
access Redis and will still honor the other bits of TLS everywhere
configuration. Also, make that change limited to HA and allow
non-HA stack to connect to Redis over a TLS tunnel.

Change-Id: I3b50ebf50046d33d49fbb555c2ee3bc6b3c2eaf9
Partial-Bug: 1784205

commit_message:
add tempest full neutron src zuul job

As part of the migration to zuul v3 the legacy-tempest-dsvm-neutron-src
was created with the end goal of replacing the legacy job with a v3
based job. This patch adds a new in-repo zuul v3 job that runs the
tempest full suite with neutron/master that will replace the legacy
job.

See https://review.openstack.org/#/c/587112/ for details on removing
the legacy job from neutron-lib in the project-config.

Change-Id: I175969c989c4c3a287693691579b3ec6ae8bdad2

Add OVS-DPDK parameter as part of roles file

Adding mandatory OVS-DPDK parameter to the roles file instead of
environment file, as it requires to be added for each custom role.

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-22 12:24:36.000000000', 'message': "Switch swift to use different inventory_hostname

Our role tests execute as non-root users, and the roles
need to access the environment variables for that non-root
user. Ansible, when targeting localhost, changes to
'connection: local' and thus breaks everything we need
to do against localhost as root unless we use 'become: true',
but we if generally use that against remote hosts we lose
the environment variables for the non-root user.

As such, we switch the inventory to target 'swift-host1'
instead, which has the address '127.0.0.1', so that we do not
have to deal with the implict connection type changes implemented
by Ansible.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/584632
Change-Id: I7f2de9d1afa25f385ab4b174da1cc4d27db55338
"}, {'created': '2018-07-22 12:38:49.000000000', 'message': "Switch swift to use different inventory_hostname

Our role tests execute as non-root users, and the roles
need to access the environment variables for that non-root
user. Ansible, when targeting localhost, changes to
'connection: local' and thus breaks everything we need
to do against localhost as root unless we use 'become: true',
but we if generally use that against remote hosts we lose
the environment variables for the non-root user.

As such, we switch the inventory to target 'swift-host1'
instead, which has the address '127.0.0.1', so that we do not
have to deal with the implict connection type changes implemented
by Ansible.

We also add the rabbitmq/oslomsg groups to the inventory as they
are now required by the keystone role.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/584632
Change-Id: I7f2de9d1afa25f385ab4b174da1cc4d27db55338
"}, {'created': '2018-07-25 07:28:23.000000000', 'message': "Switch swift to use different inventory_hostname

Our role tests execute as non-root users, and the roles
need to access the environment variables for that non-root
user. Ansible, when targeting localhost, changes to
'connection: local' and thus breaks everything we need
to do against localhost as root unless we use 'become: true',
but we if generally use that against remote hosts we lose
the environment variables for the non-root user.

As such, we switch the inventory to target 'swift-host1'
instead, which has the address '127.0.0.1', so that we do not
have to deal with the implict connection type changes implemented
by Ansible.

We also add the rabbitmq/oslomsg groups to the inventory as they
are now required by the keystone role.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/584632
Change-Id: I7f2de9d1afa25f385ab4b174da1cc4d27db55338

commit_message:
Switch swift to use different inventory_hostname

Our role tests execute as non-root users, and the roles
need to access the environment variables for that non-root
user. Ansible, when targeting localhost, changes to
'connection: local' and thus breaks everything we need
to do against localhost as root unless we use 'become: true',
but we if generally use that against remote hosts we lose
the environment variables for the non-root user.

As such, we switch the inventory to target 'swift-host1'
instead, which has the address '127.0.0.1', so that we do not
have to deal with the implict connection type changes implemented
by Ansible.

We also add the rabbitmq/oslomsg groups to the inventory as they
are now required by the keystone role.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/584632
Change-Id: I7f2de9d1afa25f385ab4b174da1cc4d27db55338

[{'created': '2018-07-26 17:34:33.000000000', 'message': 'Add release note for force delete MV fix

Change Ida04fc8a7a7af541547ea196a3cbb5a287714eea fixed an issue where we
were checking the wrong microversion for support of the force delete
functionality. This adds a release note to call out that previously this
call might have been working when using a lower microversion but will no
longer be allowed.

Related-bug: #1783028

Change-Id: I660c934da053b576f817cdd349949873b0c30193
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Add release note for force delete MV fix

Change Ida04fc8a7a7af541547ea196a3cbb5a287714eea fixed an issue where we
were checking the wrong microversion for support of the force delete
functionality. This adds a release note to call out that previously this
call might have been working when using a lower microversion but will no
longer be allowed.

Related-bug: #1783028

Change-Id: I660c934da053b576f817cdd349949873b0c30193
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

@itzik,
Well, not exactly, the test is composed of the following steps:

step 5 as standalone - is fine.

But when we run steps 1-5, sometimes we get false negative that may cause to gate failure.

commit_message:
Get rid of cmp() usage and randomize pod labels

cmp() builtin is not available in Python 3. This commit removes its
usages. It also turns out we were comparing int to string in
assertNotEqual() in Services tests, so that was always passing.

Also tests were interfering with each other as labels added for pods in
Services tests were hardcoded. That's fixed here as well.

Change-Id: I37a5805f7670f905db24ddf86d3a4b4839453a6d

[{'created': '2018-07-30 17:16:15.000000000', 'message': 'python-shade expose MTU setting.

The networking API v2 specification, which is implemented by
openstack neutron, features an optional MTU parameter - when
creating a network, this allows operators to specify the value
for the maximum transmission unit value.

Change-Id: I288f02551555fff3e8b350fc6d7c6ae8f60c405c
